awd_titl_txt: Integrating species traits into species pools: A multi-scale approach to understanding community assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Human activities are profoundly altering ecosystems worldwide through changes to natural disturbance regimes and the availability of nutrients. The ability to predict the effects of human activities on biodiversity remains poor because biodiversity responds differently to similar changes in environmental conditions. This project tackles an unexplored mechanism for observed highly variable responses among communities, which is the diversity of species traits in a region.  The project will contribute new insights into the responses of biodiversity to human perturbations. It will simultaneously advance conservation, management, and restoration of human-altered ecosystems both through application of research results and through new educational and training programs. Activities will include a workshop to bring together land managers and scientists from local, state, and federal institutions to identify and discuss key challenges in conservation and restoration; training of high school students, teachers, and undergraduate students in science and field research; and dissemination of a classroom module to high school teachers focused on environmental restoration and sustainability.

The researchers will conduct a landscape-scale field experiment to examine why the diversity and composition of plant communities change in response to fire and nutrient availability in Ozark forest ecosystems. Within this large-scale experiment, plant communities will be assembled from pools of species that vary in diversity of seed, root, stem, and leaf traits. Experimental data will be combined with spatial analyses and simulation models to test how trait diversity influences the relative importance of ecological processes underlying plant community assembly. This multi-scale approach will advance our understanding of how regional variation in species-trait diversity, landscape-scale disturbances, and local variation in environmental conditions independently and interactively shape patterns of biodiversity.

por.por_cntn:
Humans are altering ecosystems worldwide through changes to disturbance regimes and environmental conditions. The ecological impacts of human activities are challenging to predict because biodiversity often responds very differently to similar changes in the environment. Such variable responses present major obstacles to understanding the variation in biodiversity that we observe in nature, as well as the impact of that biodiversity on the services that ecosystems provide. In this project we explored a key ecological mechanism to explain the variable responses of biodiversity to environmental change: the diversity of species traits in the region from which local ecological communities assemble (regional trait diversity). Our project combined field experiments in forest-plant communities, comparative studies across temperate and tropical forests, and syntheses of ecological concepts and data.

 

For our principal experiment, we tested how regional trait diversity influences responses of forest-plant communities to environmental change (fire disturbance) in the Missouri Ozarks. As in many other ecosystems worldwide, prescribed fires have become an important tool used by land managers to restore plant and animal diversity in habitats where historical fire regimes have been altered or suppressed by humans. We established a landscape-scale field experiment consisting of pairs of large forest plots, each containing a plot burned with prescribed fires and an unburned control plot. In each burned and unburned plot, we used a seed-addition experiment to assemble woody plant communities from treatments containing species with either low or high diversity of seed and seedling traits that influence plant regeneration. Our experiment supported the hypothesis that regional trait diversity determines how plant communities respond to environmental change. Seedling communities assembled from the high trait-diversity treatment had the highest variation in community composition across habitats, especially in burned forests. Fire also increased the number of species in seed-addition plots, likely by increasing resources and space for seedling establishment. These findings suggest that fire disturbance is most likely to increase biodiversity when post-fire environments are assembled from landscapes or regions that contain a high diversity of species traits.

 

In a companion experiment, we explored the interplay of fire disturbance, seed dispersal, and predation on plant species diversity. In each burned and unburned forest plot, we excluded predators (mammalian herbivores & seed predators) using fences and compared these plots to unfenced control plots. The effect of seed dispersal on plant diversity was mediated by both fire and predation. Seed dispersal increased species diversity more in burned communities and when predators were excluded. These findings provide insights into ecological processes that can guide restoration of plant communities following fires, a topic of widespread interest among land managers using prescribed fires to conserve and restore human-altered ecosystems.

 

We have disseminated our results through: 27 publications in 16 scientific journals; 2 PhD theses; 4 undergraduate honors theses; 15 presentations at scientific conferences; 18 invited research talks; and 14 high school and undergraduate student presentations at midwestern research symposia at Washington University in St. Louis, the University of Chicago, and Indiana State University. Our field projects have been featured in the Smithsonian Forest Global Earth Observatory (ForestGEO) News Blog, Smithsonian Magazine, St. Louis Public Radio, and the Washington University Magazine and Newsroom. 

 

Our project provided training in field research and educational outreach for more than 70 participants spanning high-school students to postdoctoral researchers. High school and undergraduate students participated in our project through summer research programs at Washington University's environmental field station, Tyson Research Center. To date, 26 high school students from 17 St. Louis high schools participated in the project through two field research career-exploration programs for pre-college youth coordinated through Tyson Research Center and the Missouri Botanical Garden. In addition, 27 undergraduate students from 9 universities participated in the project as full-time summer researchers in the Tyson Undergraduate Fellows Program. The project also provided training in research and mentoring for 13 research technicians, 4 graduate students, and 1 postdoctoral researcher. Through a variety of local, national, and international outreach activities, our project has provided teachers, young people, and the public with exposure to ecological field research.

 

Our landscape-scale fire experiment has expanded research collaborations and provided infrastructure for long-term research at Washington University's environmental field station. The large size of our experimental-forest plots and prescribed fires has provided infrastructure for new projects involving more than 20 researchers (6 staff scientists, 6 graduate students, 4 professors, 3 postdoctoral researchers, 2 postbaccalaureate researchers, 1 restoration biologist) from several local institutions, including the University of Missouri St. Louis, the Missouri Botanical Garden and Shaw Nature Reserve, National Great Rivers Research and Education Center, and the Washington University McKelvey School of Engineering and School of Medicine. These projects explore a wide range of complementary questions related to fire ecology including air quality and atmospheric chemistry, animal-movement ecology, ant ecology and seed dispersal, climate microrefugia, invasive insect species, and tick-borne disease ecology.
